bestBHT.bht: Write therefore the vision of the Glorified Christ, signifying the things which thou sawest and what things they are. The things which are represent the present state of the churches when John was writing, while the things which shall be refer to the future history of the Church, blending the past, present, and future into a single view. This vision is given by the First and Last, who holds the keys of death and offers it for the comfort and warning of the Church.

Henry Alford: Write therefore...the things which thou sawest...and what things they are

Both on account of the construction in the original...and because the verb are, unquestionably in this meaning of signify, occurs twice in the next verse, I have no hesitation in taking this latter meaning
the things which shall be will by analogy mean the things which shall succeed these, i.e. a future vision
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Write therefore" (inasmuch as I, "the First and Last," have the keys of death, and vouchsafe to thee this vision for the comfort and warning of the Church).
The things which are" imply the present state of things in the churches when John was writing, as represented in the second and third chapters.
The things which shall be hereafter," the things symbolically represented concerning the future history of the fourth through twenty-second chapters.
Albert Barnes: Write the things which thou hast seen ... Give an account of those things which thou hast seen as designed to represent the condition of the seven churches."

He had seen not only the Saviour, but he had seen seven lampstands, and seven stars in the hand of the Saviour, and he is now commanded to record the meaning of these symbols as referring to things then actually existing in the seven churches.

He was to make a correct representation of the things which then were, and then to record what would occur 'after these things:' to wit, of the images, symbols, and truths, which would be disclosed to him after what he had already seen.
Philip Schaff: Write, seeing that I am what I have now revealed Myself to be.
The things which are' then give expression to the present condition of the Church, as she follows her Lord in humiliation and suffering in the world.
'The things which shall come to pass after these things' to the glory that awaits her when, all her trials over, she shall enter upon her reward in the world to come.
Archibald T. Robertson: In view of Christ's words about himself.
The vision of the Glorified Christ.
Blending in a single view the future.
John Gill: Write the things which thou hast seen... for it does not refer to what he had seen of Christ in the days of his flesh, but to what he had now seen in this representation of him." (38 words)
and the things which are; the state of the churches of Christ in the apostolic age, and at that time signified by the Ephesian church." (26 words)
and the things which shall be hereafter; from hence unto the end of the world, in successive generations." (20 words)
John Wesley: Write the things which thou hast seen — This day: which accordingly are written, Revelation 1:11-18.
And which are — The instructions relating to the present state of the seven churches. These are written, Revelation 1:20-Re.
And which shall be hereafter — To the end of the world; written, Revelation 4:1, etc.

bhtAttempts.bht: Write the things which thou sawest, the vision of the Glorified Christ blending the future history of the Church, for it signifies the things that shall succeed these. The things which are represent the present state of the churches as they follow Christ in the world, while the things which shall be hereafter reveal the glory that awaits the Church in the world to come. Thus, this verse encompasses a comprehensive view of the Church's past, present, and future, as guided by the First and Last, who holds the keys of death and offers this vision for the comfort and warning of the Church.

Write the vision of the Glorified Christ, signifying the things that shall succeed these. The things which are represent the present state of the churches, while the things which shall be hereafter reveal the glory that awaits the Church. Thus, this comprehensive view encompasses the Church's past, present, and future, as guided by the First and Last, who offers this vision for the comfort and warning of the Church.

Write the vision of the Glorified Christ as a comprehensive view of the Church's past, present, and future. The things which are symbolize the present state of the churches, while the things which shall be hereafter reveal the glory that awaits the Church. This vision is offered by the First and Last, who holds the keys of death and provides it for the comfort and warning of the Church.

Write therefore the vision of the Glorified Christ, signifying the things which thou sawest and what things they are. The things which are represent the present state of the churches when John was writing, while the things which shall be refer to the future history of the Church, blending the past, present, and future into a single view. This vision is given by the First and Last, who holds the keys of death and offers it for the comfort and warning of the Church.

Write therefore the vision of the Glorified Christ representing the future history of the Church. The things which are symbolize the present state of the churches, while the things which shall be blend the past, present, and future into a single view. This vision is given by the First and Last, who holds the keys of death, for the comfort and warning of the Church.
